channel.title: misc on rs.io
channel.description: Recent content in misc on rs.io

item.title: Fixing VirtIO Code 39
item.description: I’m recording this here in case anyone else is unfortunate enough to encounter this Code 39 message, and so that she can avoid wasting several hours of her life attempting to fix it, by instead Googling it and reading this.

item.title: Tiger Petting, Not That Dangerous
item.description: I was not designed to be forced. —Henry David Thoreau, On the Duty of Civil Disobedience

item.title: Results From The First Split Test
item.description: Measuring gives you a leg up on experts who are too good to measure.

item.title: How the 2013 Boston Marathon Bombings Affected This Year’s Attendance
item.description: A year ago, I logged a prediction (at 60% confidence) that this year’s Boston Marathon attendance would be lower than the previous year’s as a result of the 2013 bombings.

item.title: 100+ Interesting Data Sets for Statistics
item.description: If we have data, let’s look at data. If all we have are opinions, let’s go with mine.

item.title: Surprisingly Dangerous Jobs In America
item.description: You can’t avoid danger. —Jeannette Walls, Half Broke Horses

item.title: What I’m Watching
item.description: From most recommended to least (roughly): The movie Manufacturing Consent details Noam Chomsky’s criticism of the media, covering Indonesia’s invasion of East Timor and media bias generally.

item.title: Hard Books Are Overrated
item.description: Hot air balloons take people on adventures. Books do, too.

item.title: Response to BasicBookReader
item.description: How can e-readers be improved? This is a response to Austin G.

item.title: Too Smart To Understand
item.description: Here is a meme I would very much like to see die forever.

item.title: Anki Tips: What I Learned Making 10,000 Flashcards
item.description: If you don’t know what Anki or spaced repetition is, start by reading gwern’s excellent introduction.

item.title: Red Pill Rhetoric: Swallowing the Red Pill Isn’t
item.description: You take the blue pill, the story ends. You wake up in your bed and believe whatever you want to believe.

item.title: Fox News Versus MSNBC: Who’s More Opinionated?
item.description: Listening to the internet, you’d think that Fox News is some sort of liberal boogeyman — the lowest of the low that is modern journalism.

item.title: Software For Writers: Tools To Improve Your Writing
item.description: There are two types of writer — the snobs and the engineers.

item.title: Does the internet lie? (Hint: Yes.)
item.description: Yesterday, I saw someone spin this very plausible theory about why it’s so repellent when someone brags about their IQ on the internet.

item.title: Overcoming Writer’s Block: Narrow To Generate Ideas
item.description: Heuristic: Focus on concrete categories when generating ideas.

item.title: Online Community Building: Why Communities Decay
item.description: The first day of September 1993 was the beginning of an eternal September, a calendar month whose days stretched to infinity.

item.title: 4chan Is What Free Speech On The Internet Looks Like
item.description: Meditation: If there are true things that no one is allowed to say, how will you know them?

item.title: Does race exist?
item.description: No one in her left brain could reject reductionism.

item.title: Could OSX’s Spotlight Suck More? Doubt It
item.description: There was a post about a week ago about how new computer science students don’t get the Unix philosophy and the power (and great responsibility) of the command line.
